articles.headline: Big Deals Like Bayer’s Often Fail to Deliver High Performance
articles.snippet: An S&P Global study found that companies more often than not underperform their peers after making a large acquisition.
articles.abstract: An S&P Global study found that companies more often than not underperform their peers after making a large acquisition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Plenty of people have reason to celebrate the $56 billion bid by Bayer AG, the German pharmaceuticals giant, for Monsanto, the United States agribusiness company.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Warned Workers Against Sham Accounts, but ‘They Needed a Paycheck’
articles.snippet: Former employees say that their managers warned them not to bend the rules, but they felt pressured by the bank’s aggressive sales culture to create fake accounts anyway.
articles.abstract: Former employees say that their managers warned them not to bend the rules, but they felt pressured by the bank’s aggressive sales culture to create fake accounts anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: The message to the dozens of Wells Fargo workers gathered for a two-day ethics workshop in San Diego in mid-2014 was loud and clear: Do not create fake bank accounts in the name of unsuspecting clients.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Donald Trump Clung to ‘Birther’ Lie for Years, and Still Isn’t Apologetic
articles.snippet: It was never true. Any of it. And even as Mr. Trump surrendered to the reality of President Obama’s birthplace, he insisted on conjuring a new falsehood.
articles.abstract: It was never true. Any of it. And even as Mr. Trump surrendered to the reality of President Obama’s birthplace, he insisted on conjuring a new falsehood.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was not true in 2011, when Donald J. Trump mischievously began to question President Obama’s birthplace aloud in television interviews. “I’m starting to think that he was not born here,” he said at the time.

articles.headline: Rush of Chinese Investment in Europe’s High-Tech Firms Is Raising Eyebrows
articles.snippet: A Chinese spree of buying top European tech companies is raising questions about the origins of the funds and the acquirers’ intentions.
articles.abstract: A Chinese spree of buying top European tech companies is raising questions about the origins of the funds and the acquirers’ intentions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After a customer canceled a large order at the last minute, shares in Aixtron, a German high-tech company, sank fast. Months later, with the stock still reeling, a Chinese investor agreed to buy the company.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Inspired by the U.S., West Africans Wield Smartphones to Fight Police Abuse
articles.snippet: Citizens are increasingly deploying social media in nations where corruption and abuse by security forces sometimes occur with few repercussions.
articles.abstract: Citizens are increasingly deploying social media in nations where corruption and abuse by security forces sometimes occur with few repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The YouTube video shows a grim scene from Ivory Coast: An unarmed man lies on a street with his arms up. A police officer fires a shot that appears to strike him.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Jaime Yaya Barry

articles.headline: Who’s Too Young for an App? Musical.ly Tests the Limits
articles.snippet: The video-sharing app Musical.ly seems to be popular with children well under the age of 13, which leads to questions over how to monitor young people on the web.
articles.abstract: The video-sharing app Musical.ly seems to be popular with children well under the age of 13, which leads to questions over how to monitor young people on the web.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the folklore of the start-up world, few figures loom larger than the teenager. Teenagers see the future, set trends and spend money, or compel parents to spend it for them. Their behavior has become an obsession for entrepreneurs.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Most Voters Embrace Milestone for Women, if Not Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: The survey found that women think that more progress has been made toward ending sexism than racism in society, but they perceive that men still hold advantages.
articles.abstract: The survey found that women think that more progress has been made toward ending sexism than racism in society, but they perceive that men still hold advantages.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 8, American voters for the first time in history will see a woman’s name on the ballot as a major party’s nominee for president. A broad majority of voters — men and women — say they are happy this milestone has been reached, but fully half of them say they would have preferred that that first woman not be Hillary Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Mary Jo Murphy and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Donald Trump Says Hillary Clinton’s Bodyguards Should Disarm to ‘See What Happens to Her’
articles.snippet: The Republican nominee again raised the possibility of violence against his opponent, saying of her Secret Service agents, “Take their guns away.”
articles.abstract: The Republican nominee again raised the possibility of violence against his opponent, saying of her Secret Service agents, “Take their guns away.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Donald J. Trump once again raised the specter of violence against Hillary Clinton, suggesting Friday that the Secret Service agents who guard her voluntarily disarm to “see what happens to her” without their protection.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Nicholas Confessore and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: A Sour Surprise for Public Pensions: Two Sets of Books
articles.snippet: The plight of a tiny local retirement fund in California shows how some public pension plans are far less funded than their official numbers suggest.
articles.abstract: The plight of a tiny local retirement fund in California shows how some public pension plans are far less funded than their official numbers suggest.
articles.lead_paragraph: When one of the tiniest pension funds imaginable — for Citrus Pest Control District No. 2, serving just six people in California — decided last year to convert itself to a 401(k) plan, it seemed like a no-brainer.

articles.headline: A Chicago Shooting Survivor, but in Need of a Miracle
articles.snippet: Sixty-four people were shot in the city over Memorial Day weekend; 6 died. The 58 survivors, including Precious Land, were mostly left to languish in anonymity.
articles.abstract: Sixty-four people were shot in the city over Memorial Day weekend; 6 died. The 58 survivors, including Precious Land, were mostly left to languish in anonymity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a spacious room on the fourth floor of a rehabilitation hospital, Stacey Turner talked to her only daughter, Precious Land, as if she could understand every word. She styled Ms. Land’s hair, massaged her hands and set out to paint her fingernails. The only sound was the whirring of a ventilator.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Gain Traction in Florida, Despite Spending
articles.snippet: Recent polls show Mrs. Clinton is not earning the same support of Hispanics, young people or white voters as President Obama did in 2012, which offers Donald J. Trump an opening.
articles.abstract: Recent polls show Mrs. Clinton is not earning the same support of Hispanics, young people or white voters as President Obama did in 2012, which offers Donald J. Trump an opening.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Hillary Clinton has vastly outspent Donald J. Trump on TV ads in Florida. Her 57 campaign offices dwarf Mr. Trump’s afterthought of a ground game. And Mr. Trump is deeply unpopular among Hispanics, who account for nearly one in five Florida voters.

articles.headline: U.S. Admits Airstrike in Syria, Meant to Hit ISIS, Killed Syrian Troops
articles.snippet: The United States military said the planes stopped the attack after a warning from Russia, which said 62 Syrian troops were killed and 100 more wounded.
articles.abstract: The United States military said the planes stopped the attack after a warning from Russia, which said 62 Syrian troops were killed and 100 more wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United States acknowledged on Saturday that its warplanes had carried out an airstrike in Syria that resulted in the deaths of Syrian government troops. American military officials said the pilots in the attack, in the eastern province of Deir al-Zour, believed they were targeting the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: ‘We Built an App’: Keeping Track of Louisiana’s Flood-Tossed Tombs
articles.snippet: This year’s floodwaters and a history of hurricanes have highlighted the state’s need for a macabre and peculiar undertaking: cemetery recovery.
articles.abstract: This year’s floodwaters and a history of hurricanes have highlighted the state’s need for a macabre and peculiar undertaking: cemetery recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENHAM SPRINGS, La. — On a steamy hot afternoon, Arbie Goings was out looking for the itinerant dead.

articles.headline: Coming Soon, Economists Hope: Big Spending on Roads, Bridges and Ports
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump and many economists support investing billions in the nation’s crumbling infrastructure, but paying for it won’t be simple.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump and many economists support investing billions in the nation’s crumbling infrastructure, but paying for it won’t be simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The docks at the Port of Oakland are a tangle of cranes, shipping containers, railroad tracks and snaking lines of trucks waiting to load and unload cargo.

articles.headline: How Tech Companies Disrupted Silicon Valley’s Restaurant Scene
articles.snippet: Restaurants in Palo Alto are increasingly struggling as rents soar and workers are hired away by the corporate cafeterias of behemoths like Google.
articles.abstract: Restaurants in Palo Alto are increasingly struggling as rents soar and workers are hired away by the corporate cafeterias of behemoths like Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It wasn’t so long ago that the aroma of Moroccan spiced prawns and wood-oven pizzas wafted out to a downtown street here from the open-air patio of a once popular eatery called Zibibbo.

articles.headline: Adblock Plus, Created to Protect Users From Ads, Instead Opens the Door
articles.snippet: With its new platform, an automated online service, the company will allow more websites to place ads in front of users.
articles.abstract: With its new platform, an automated online service, the company will allow more websites to place ads in front of users.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adblock Plus, an ad blocker now used on more than 100 million devices, started out as an almost utopian idea a decade ago. Wladimir Palant, a 20-something developer who was annoyed with intrusive ads online, created it as an open-source project and quickly built it up with the help of volunteers who also wanted to make the internet faster, less cluttered and safer from malware.

articles.headline: How a U.S. Airstrike Missed ISIS, but Damaged U.S. Policy in Syria
articles.snippet: The accidental killing of Syrian soldiers again exposed the White House’s struggles to put together a coherent strategy in a multisided civil war.
articles.abstract: The accidental killing of Syrian soldiers again exposed the White House’s struggles to put together a coherent strategy in a multisided civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States’ accidental bombing of Syrian troops over the weekend has put it on the defensive, undercutting American efforts to reduce violence in the civil war and open paths for humanitarian relief.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Mark Mazzetti and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Larry King, the Russian Media and a Partisan Landscape
articles.snippet: The presence of the cable talk show hosts Larry King and Ed Schultz on the United States feed of Russia Today, the satellite media organization funded by the Russian government, has raised eyebrows.
articles.abstract: The presence of the cable talk show hosts Larry King and Ed Schultz on the United States feed of Russia Today, the satellite media organization funded by the Russian government, has raised eyebrows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, I caught Larry King on his post-CNN media perch, the RT America television network. His guest, the actress and activist Kamala Lopez, was powerfully emotional as she called for the ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment.

articles.headline: Obama Sees ‘Personal Insult’ if Blacks Don’t Rally for Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: Many Democrats are afraid that Mrs. Clinton’s large edge among African-American voters may be undercut by apathy and low voter turnout.
articles.abstract: Many Democrats are afraid that Mrs. Clinton’s large edge among African-American voters may be undercut by apathy and low voter turnout.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Democratic leaders increasingly worried about a lack of passion for Hillary Clinton among young black voters, President Obama is rolling out a new and more personal campaign message: “It’s about me.”
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: ‘Trust Your Gut’ Might Actually Be Profitable Advice on Wall Street, Study Says
articles.snippet: A study published on Monday in Scientific Reports suggests that high-frequency traders who were more sensitive to their bodies made more profitable trades.
articles.abstract: A study published on Monday in Scientific Reports suggests that high-frequency traders who were more sensitive to their bodies made more profitable trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: What attributes make for a successful trader? Is it comprehensive knowledge of an industry? The ability to read the markets? Luck?

articles.headline: After Bombings, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Clash Over Terrorism
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton stressed her national security credentials and measured her words, and Mr. Trump sounded a note of furious alarm about Saturday’s attacks in New York and New Jersey.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton stressed her national security credentials and measured her words, and Mr. Trump sounded a note of furious alarm about Saturday’s attacks in New York and New Jersey.
articles.lead_paragraph: A suspect in a bombing was still at large Monday morning, his motives and intentions unknown — but Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump were already racing to seize the political upper hand.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Nicholas Confessore
